text:
“Let’s talk about
record of the year.”

“Well, here’s the
question, Joe:
There’s 10 songs —

are we going to talk
about 10 or eight?”

“We’re going to talk
about all 10 of them.”

“I really don’t like the
category being this big.”

“Among these 10 songs, there’s
really only two options.”

“Just to be very frank, I
had not listened to at least

a few of these songs
prior to, like, this week.”
“This is one weird playlist.

If you put this on and
walk away, you’re like,

Where am I, and
what is happening?”

“Record of the Year
is maybe the one

of the four big
categories where

the Grammys can basically be
like, Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah,
we get it.
We get it.
It’s a big song.”

“I think it should be an
award for the song that truly
defined the year.
It’s a tall order.”

“When you think of the
year in music 2021,

who else comes to
mind but Abba?”
[laughs] “Yes!”

“Abba is amazing
in so many ways,

but this song is not, like,
twirling in ecstasy around

the dance floor Abba, like,
high-fiving your girlfriends

and having a glass
of wine Abba.”

“What does it
sound like to you?”
“Man, it sounds funereal.”

“This song is like
the national anthem
of a failed monarchy.”

“You listen to this, and how
do you not see somebody

sternly at the bow of
a ship, waving a flag?”
“Why is it here?
This song has the line,

‘I hear a bittersweet song
in the memories we share.’

True, Abba was
great in the ’70s,
didn’t get any Grammys.”

“It’s a make-good. The refs are
giving them one because they

didn’t call it
fairly in the past.”

“The craziest thing I could
say about this song is it —

it could win
record of the year.”

“What would it mean for
the Grammys’ credibility,

or whatever’s left of it,
if Abba ends up taking home
record of the year?”

“If this song wins,
that’s when we, like —
like, like,

that’s when we
get up and leave.”
“‘Kiss Me More,’
Doja Cat featuring SZA —

one of the biggest
songs of the year.
Do you like it?”
[laughs]

“You didn’t like last
year’s Doja Cat song.”
[music: Doja Cat, “Say So”]

[singing] “I’d let
you had I known it.
Why don’t you say so?”

“This, to me, is
the same song.”
“It’s ‘Say So, Part Two.’”
“Dojo?
Great rapper.”
“Great Rapper.”
“Spits, just spits hard.

If you get into the kind of
syllabic stuff in the verse —
killer.”

[singing] “Sign first, middle,
last on the wisdom tooth.

And they wishin’ that the
cookie was a kissin’ booth.

Taste breakfast, lunch,
and gin and juice.

And that dinner just
like dessert, too.”

“And I know that she’s
traditionally known
as an edgy artist.

There’s just something about
the music to me dulls her
edges.
I just want her to go crazy.

I just want to hear
something wild from her.

These songs just
feel really safe.”

“It sounds like
X-rated bubble gum.”

“As far as X-rated
bubble gum goes,

I would say ‘Montero’ is
is also in that ballpark.”

“The ‘Montero’ song is a whole
different musical universe.”

“‘Montero (Call Me
By Your Name)’—

the second defining song
of Lil Nas X’s career.
But is it good?
Hold on, scratch that.
But is it music?”

[laughter] “That’s
ice cold, dog.

I, as a critic and a
listener, do not even remotely
mind songs that sound plastic.

The degree of plasticity on
this song is overwhelming.

It really feels like it is
composed of spare parts.”
“No, the song is confused to me.”
“It’s in a weird minor mode.

It’s got a little
Middle Eastern flavor.
It’s got flamenco flavor.”

[singing] "Cocaine and
drinking with your friends.”

“This is, like, give me
something strange.”

“But like with all things
Lil Nas X, boy,

he’s so special because it’s
never just about the song.

It’s about all the things
that come with the song.

When I hear this song,
I don’t think about the song.

I think about him
tearing his pants on ‘SNL.’

I think about him
making out with his dancer
on the BET Awards.

I think about all the ways
he’s trolled everybody with

this song, about the brilliant
video, the Nikes, Satan.

It’s just, like — 
it’s not a song,
it’s a movement.”

“I mean, this would be a great
song for the 1934 Grammys.”
[laughs] “Right.”

[singing] “Mere alcohol
doesn’t thrill me at all.”

“I love it for the
first 45 seconds.
I think it’s beautiful.

When it’s just the two
of them and that piano,
there’s an intimacy there.

I mean, the love is a thing
I can hear in the song.”

[singing] “When I’m out on
a quiet spree, fighting
vainly the old ennui.”

“And then the
rest of the song,

I just lose interest because
it’s hewing to a thing that

somebody thinks that
song is supposed to do.”

“This one is just — let’s
go to the vintage factory.”

“I don’t know if
the Tony Bennett,
Lady Gaga song is good.

It doesn’t exist on the same
matrix as any of these other
records.

It only exists to
receive this nomination.”
“It’s a tip of the hat.
It’s a final ovation.
You’ve earned it, Tony.
You’ve had a great career.

A song from the ’30s, recorded
in its umpteenth version —
it’s fine.
It’s fine.”
“It’s fine.”
“It’s fine.
It’s fine.”
“Do you like the song?”
“Not much.”
“I don’t like this song.”

“I don’t like the chorus
of this song at all.”

“Even though the three verses
are, to my ear, distinct,

the song itself doesn’t
change very much.

It doesn’t feel like
a dynamic song.”

“It just feels like
fancy resort wear,
like loungewear.

The problem with it is that
there’s no friction anywhere.
There’s no tension.
There’s no texture.”

“And like all
committee-produced music,

it’s intricately done, but
there’s not much there-there."

“And that muffled piano at
the beginning of the song —
I love that.

That’s my favorite part 
of the whole song.

[laughs] “This is a
good year for pianos.”

“Because she’s capable
of so much better,

it’s kind of a bummer to see
this song nominated here.

It’s, like, you know
what she’s capable of.

She’s one of the only people
in the past few years who

turned the Grammys into
the kind of platform that

completely changed
her life and career.”
[music]

“My only note on the Brandi
Carlile song is it’s not

as good as the old
Brandi Carlile songs.”
“Right.”

“You listen to this
song — it’s, like —
it’s a power ballad.

You know, her voice
is always great.

It’s going to take
you somewhere.

But it’s, like, it’s
just hard to really —

it does not have 
the same zhuzh.

It doesn’t have
the same juice.

It doesn’t have
the same build.”

“I also don’t follow
the story, really.”

“I feel like, from a lyrical
perspective, it has, like,
a modicum of complexity.
It’s about, um —”
“It’s sort of like she’s, uh, —

somebody who’s
at war with, uh —”

“I feel like it’s a song
about depression or, um —
[Expletive] Who knows, man?
[laughs]

“That’s what I
was going to say.

Everyone here tries to
explain what’s it about.

It’s like, oh, you know,
uh, they’re fighting.”

“I’m very excited
about this song.
It’s really four songs, right?

From the beginning, it’s one
of her traditional-minded

crooner songs. But
then something happens.

It briefly becomes a
contemporary pop song.”

[singing] “I don’t
relate to you, no.”

“But then it explodes into,
like, this lush rock anthem.

It’s like a Yeah Yeah
Yeahs song or something,

or just, like, Oh, I see
what’s happening here.

And it ends in this electronic
squall, which, to me,
is song four.”

“It’s not — it’s not even
the best song on this album.”

“There’s also a sequence of
rhymes in this song that I
wrote down.

She few rhymes ‘again,’ ‘bends,’
‘influence,’ ‘death,’ ‘breath,’
and ‘friends.’

That is a genius
imperfect rhyming.”

“The thing that I love about
it are also the, like —

the nice little Radiohead
tributes at the end of that
song.”
[singing] “Oh.”

“Of these songs, I’d
argue it’s in the top half
of the songs.”

“Does this song
speak for 2021?”
“No.”
[laughs]

“The song speaks to,
like, 1977, maybe?”

“Yeah, I had not heard
this song prior to its
nomination.”
“Will you ever hear it again?”

“I mean, yeah, in a
Chrysler commercial.”

“I mean, for this song, all
I have to say is it’s funky,
and it’s familiar.”

“He does lead a
late-night band.
He’s Mr. Cover Artist.”
[singing] “You make me feel —”

“It’s studied, but I
like what he's studying.”

“You know, he’s honoring all
of the music in his life,
from trap to jazz.”

“This is a really familiar
Grammy type of record in that
it’s a song about a song.”
“It’s vegetables.”
“Disguised as candy?”
“I don’t know.

Do you eat this
kind of candy?”
[laughs] “No.”

“Grammys don’t want
anything too divisive.

Freedom is a very
non-divisive concept.”

“Convince me this is not
the record of the year.”
“Could be.”
“I was like, holy [expletive].
This is good.
This is a good song.”
“Yeah.”

“There is so much
to hear in that song.”

[singing] “Today I drove
through the suburbs.”
“I love the piano.

All the strange, swooping
sounds to the big chorus.”

“It has an amazing vocal
line. That ascending line,

a sort of pre-chorus,
I imagine,

is creating all sorts
of karaoke calamities.”
[singing] “I just —”
[singing] “can’t imagine —”
[singing] “How you —”
[singing] “Hold me —”
[singing] “So, OK.”
[singing] [inaudible]
“It’s a great song.
Bridge of the year.”
“It’s so well made.

It’s also lovely,
sharp, eviscerating,

self-lacerating, elegantly
written, sparingly produced.
It’s thoughtful and emotional,

ecstatic but also,
like, terrifically sad.
What more do you want?”
“This is the song of 2021.”
[music: Silk Sonic, “Leave the Door Open”]

[singing] “I’mma
leave the door open.”

“I want to talk about the
comedy of this record,

given what the record
also is — like,

what the record is
being funny about.”
[singing] “You got plans.”
[singing] “You got plans.”
[singing] “Don’t say that.”
[singing] “Shut your trap.”

“And that really great
Spinners, Drifters,

Chi-Lites vibe that
they capture is —

what is the place
for a novelty record

put out by two very
serious musicians?

Let’s say everything
about this song is exactly

the same, but it’s
Lonely Island.”
[singing] “Oh!”
[singing] “It’s my [expletive] in a box.”

“So you think of it more
as parody and novelty than
homage?”
“It’s a tricky thing, right?
The performance is perfect.
It is a great record.”

“The kind of thing that they
should teach at the Berklee
School of Music.
And they probably are already.

Elaborate chord
progression, the production

that gets the little
glockenspiel nuances.
I mean, this is a how-to-make-a-record record.”

“I had the same problem that
I had with the Bieber song.

It’s so smooth that I can’t
even find a place to put
my fingers in.”

“And, so, yeah, it’s
definitely a contender.”

“What song are you
missing in this category?
What should be here?”

“Cardi B’s ‘Up.’ I think that
song got completely left out
of the year-end conversation.
[music: Cardi B, "Up"]
[singing] "Up, then it’s stuck.”

“I didn’t mind hearing
that hook a billion times.

Swiping, I watched a thousand
people dance to that song.
[laughs]

“Or lip sync to that
song, and I just —
it’s so irresistible.”
“Two words, ‘Coi Leray.’”
“Mm, OK.”
[music: Coi Leray, "Twinnem"]
[singing] “No, no friends.”

“I would say ‘Pick Up Your
Feelings.’ I don’t know why

Jazmine Sullivan is not in any
of these major categories.”
“Yeah.”
[singing] “Pick up your —”

“I think ‘Heaux Tales’ is the
Stephen Sondheim show
that never got made.”

“What’s going to win
Record of the Year?”

“Ugh, always a
tough question.”

“I never know what gets
a leg up at the Grammys.”

“All right, well,
I’ll give you 100 bucks.

Where would you
spread it around?”

“I would give $30
in Bitcoin to Abba.

And then I would put the rest
of the money with Rodrigo.”

“I want to split between
‘Montero’ and ‘Drivers
License.’”

“Assuming even odds, I
would roulette the money:

Billie, Silk
Sonic, Jon Batiste.”

“70 bucks on ‘Drivers License,’
10 bucks on Bruno, 10 bucks
on Billie.
And that leaves me $10 left.
[laughs]
“We love math.”
[laughs]

“This is why we’re
music people.”

“And the Grammy goes to
‘Bad Guy,’ Billie Eilish.”

“And the Grammy goes
to Billie Eilish.”
[cheering]

“You know, I was a little
disappointed to admit

to myself I think that Billie
should or might win this one

because I’d love to see Olivia
be coronated on that kind
of a level.

And she’s at the
beginning of her career.

It would be good for
the Grammys to be like,

We’re going to get on the
ground floor with this one

because she’s going to be
a big draw for us for years

and years to come, especially
at a time when the Grammys

seems to be having a little
bit of a problem holding
on to the top pop talent.”
[singing] “You said forever.

Now I drive alone
past your street.”

“So there are songs on this
list that you had never heard
before?”
“Yes.”

“As a professional
music critic?”
“Yeah.”

“I’m going to go ahead and
say that that’s the Grammys
problem, not yours.”
[laughs]
